awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Manufacturing of Polymer Nanofiber Arrays on Surfaces by Chemical Vapor Deposition into Liquid Crystal Templates
awd_abstract_narration:
This research grant establishes knowledge for a transformative new manufacturing process that has the potential to benefit a range of U.S. industries, creating new jobs and economic activity.  Manufacturers of electronics, food packaging and medical devices currently coat their products with thin films of plastics that function as protective barriers using a process called chemical vapor deposition.  The investigators supported by this research grant have discovered a new way to greatly expand the potential usefulness of chemical vapor deposition in manufacturing, using the process to fabricate surfaces covered with arrays of end-attached plastic nanofibers. Surfaces decorated with carpets of nanofibers exhibit properties that differ dramatically from continuous coatings, such as providing tunable optical or adhesive properties that might be used in energy-efficient and flexible displays or next generation robotics.  This award supports fundamental research needed to understand how these nanofiber films form and how their surfaces are encoded with properties useful for electronics, food and medical device industries. The advances achieved during this research have the potential to be rapidly scaled into an industrially practiced nanotechnology, bringing economic prosperity and security.  The grant also provides an outstanding opportunity for multidisciplinary training of the next generation manufacturing workforce.

The approach to be investigated in this grant involves chemical vapor deposition of polymers into thin films of liquid crystals. Specifically, chemical vapor polymerization performed on surfaces coated with micrometer-thick films of liquid crystals leads to formation of organized assemblies of end-attached polymer nanofibers with unprecedented control over organization, size (length and width), surface chemistry, chirality, and shape (straight, bent or helical).  In contrast to conventional liquid crystal-templated polymerizations, the monomer concentration in the liquid crystal phase remains low, as the monomers are formed in the vapor phase and then diffuse into the liquid crystal template. Accordingly, chemical vapor polymerization minimizes monomer-induced changes to the liquid crystal phase behavior and enables access to nanofiber arrays with precisely defined structures. Given the diverse range of liquid crystals available for use as templates for chemical vapor polymerization, this project has the potential to provide a paradigm-shifting approach for large-scale manufacturing of oriented nanofiber arrays with complex interfacial morphologies and chemistries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Chemical vapor polymerization (CVP) into liquid crystalline (LC) templates is a promising and versatile approach for advanced manufacturing of nanostructured polymeric films. However, the full spectrum of morphologies and properties of the resulting polymeric structures that are accessible by LC-templated CVP are not yet known owing to the limited understanding of key aspects of the process.  The research pursued in this project explored a series of fundamental questions that arise from a convergence of ideas from two largely disconnected fields – LCs and CVP polymers.  Specifically, the research elucidated the role of precursor and LC chemistry in guiding the chemical and physical processes that control the formation of newly discovered polymeric morphologies (e.g., nanofiber sheets) that can be accessed by CVP into LC films.

Over the duration of this project, we addressed key gaps in knowledge by achieving six key outcomes:

  • Discovery of multi-scale transfer of chirality during LC-templated CVP of chiral precursors.
  • Elucidation of the sharing of strain between nanofiber forests and LCs and emergent electro-optic properties.
  • Investigating the emergence of structural phosphorescence in freestanding, laterally organized polymer nanofiber membranes.
  • Discovery of interconnected nanofiber sheets synthesized by CVP at the free surface of liquid crystalline films.
  • Understanding the growth mechanism of nanofibers from the solid-LC interface during CVP and their convergence into hierarchical organizations.
  • Scalable fabrication of “bed-of-nails” nanostructures into ultra-thin LC templates over large areas.

The new knowledge emerging from these accomplishments has formed the basis of materials processes that substantially advance US manufacturing competitiveness and economic growth. The approach is particularly promising as it leverages the successful deployment of CVP technology used for the manufacture of continuous polymer films (e.g., parylene coatings for packaging of microelectronic components) and reveals that the introduction of LC template films expands the diversity and versatility of the polymer coating technology in remarkable and unanticipated ways. The outcomes of this project provide new approaches for large-scale manufacturing of precision polymeric nanostructures with complex interfacial morphologies and chemistries. Potential applications include adhesive coatings, biomedical sensors, biomaterials as interfaces to living cells, and selective filter membranes. Additionally, this collaborative project has provided an outstanding context for the multidisciplinary training of graduate students in next-generation manufacturing science, including collaborative approaches involving geographically separated research teams.  

 

 


Last Modified: 11/18/2023
Modified by: Nicholas L Abbott
